head.title: A House of Books, Each One a Memory

hedline.hl1: A House of Books, Each One a Memory

abstract.p: Lee Sakellarides letter on John Updike's June 18 article cites importance of books as comfort items; drawing

block.p: As John Updike states so beautifully (''Books Unbound, Life Unraveled,'' Op-Ed, June 18), books are comfort objects as much they are a means of transferring information, which seems to be the sole agenda of electronic gadgets.

As John Updike states so beautifully (''Books Unbound, Life Unraveled,'' Op-Ed, June 18), books are comfort objects as much they are a means of transferring information, which seems to be the sole agenda of electronic gadgets.

Many of my books hold clippings, photographs, pressed flowers, Mass cards and correspondence. In addition, among my most precious belongings are books inscribed to me and signed by Kurt Vonnegut, Christopher Robin Milne, Quentin Crisp and Allen Ginsberg, my former professor.
What form would these treasures take, if not books?
